raw_text:
Broadband steams ahead in the US
 
 More and more Americans are joining the internet's fast lane, according to official figures.
 
 The number of people and business connected to broadband jumped by 38% in a year, said the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC). In a report, it said there were more than 32 million broadband connections by the end of June 2004. But the US is still behind compared to other nations, ranked 13th in the world by a UN telecoms body.
 
 During his 2004 re-election campaign, President George W Bush pledge to ensure that affordable high-speed net access would be available to all Americans by 2007.
 
 According to the report by the FCC, broadband is becoming increasingly popular, with people using it for research and shopping, as well as downloading music and watching video. The total number of people and businesses on broadband rose by to 32.5 million in the year ending June 2004, compared to 23.5 million in June 2003. Whereas in the UK, most people hook up to broadband via Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL) technology which lets ordinary copper phone lines support high data speeds. But in the US, cable leads the way, accounting for 18.6 million lines. Broadband over the phone line makes up 11.4 million connections, according to the FCC figures.
llama3.2:1b:
The number of Americans and businesses connected to broadband internet grew by 38% in one year, reaching 32.5 million by June 2004.

The US lags behind other nations in terms of broadband availability and penetration, ranking 13th in the world.

President George W Bush pledged to ensure affordable high-speed net access for all Americans during his re-election campaign in 2004.
llama3.2:3b: The number of broadband connections in the US increased by 38% in a year, reaching 32.5 million by the end of June 2004. The country ranks 13th globally for broadband adoption. President George W Bush pledged affordable high-speed internet access to all Americans by 2007, but the US is still behind other nations in broadband penetration, with cable and phone lines making up a significant portion of connections.
gemma2:2b: The number of broadband subscribers in the US increased by 38% in a year, reaching 32.5 million by June 2004. The US ranked 13th globally for broadband access. President Bush's campaign promised affordable high-speed internet to all Americans by 2007. Broadband usage is rising as people use it for research, shopping, music downloads, and video streaming.  Cable dominates in the US, accounting for 18.6 million lines, while DSL technology supports broadband access in the UK.
qwen2.5:0.5b: US broadband usage increased by about 38% year-over-year as of June 2004, with 32.5 million people and businesses using it for research and shopping, downloading music, and watching video. Broadband is becoming increasingly popular in the US with ADSL technology allowing high-speed internet access over copper lines, while cable TV provides voice and data services through traditional telephone lines.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The number of Americans connected to broadband grew by 38% in a year, reaching more than 32 million by June 2004. The US is ranked 13th globally in terms of broadband usage compared to other nations. President Bush pledged affordable high-speed internet access for all Americans by 2007.
qwen2.5:3b: Broadband usage in the US has increased by 38% in a year, with more than 32 million connections by June 2004. Despite this growth, the country is ranked 13th globally for broadband access. President George W. Bush pledged to make affordable high-speed internet available to all Americans by 2007. Broadband is used for research, shopping, music downloading, and video watching. Cable leads in the US with 18.6 million connections, followed by DSL at 11.4 million.

During his 2004 re-election campaign, President George W Bush pledge to ensure that affordable high-speed net access would be available to all Americans by 2007. According to the report by the FCC, broadband is becoming increasingly popular.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence mentions that broadband is ahead in the US. The second part says more Americans are joining, and the number jumped by 38%. Then the US Federal Communications Commission reported that there were over 32 million connections by June 2004. Other nations like the UK have their own systems, such as ADSL for telephone access.

The third point is about President George W Bush's campaign pledge to provide affordable high-speed net access to all Americans by 2007. The last part talks about broadband usage: people in the US use it for research and shopping, while others on Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL) with copper phone lines.

So I need to capture these key points without too much detail. Let me structure it into a few main ideas:

1. Broadband is leading in the US as more Americans join.
2. The number of broadband connections jumped by 38% annually, over 32 million by June 2004.
3. Other nations are ranked higher than the US.
4. President Bush's campaign aims for high-speed net access by 2007.
5. Usage on broadband includes research and shopping; others use ADSL or telephone lines.

I'll make sure to mention all these points concisely, keeping it straightforward without losing any important information.
</think>

Broadband leads the US with more Americans joining the internet fast lane, with connections jumping by 38% annually to over 32 million by June 2004. Other nations are ranked higher than the US. President George W Bush's campaign aims for high-speed net access by 2007. Broadband in the US is used for research and shopping; others use ADSL or telephone lines.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US is still behind countries like Japan and Germany when it comes to accessibility of high-speed internet connectivity. Official figures reveal that more and more Americans are joining the internet's fast lane, with broadband connections jumping by 38% in a year. The country ranks 13th in the world when it comes to affordable net access, according to the UN telecoms body. However, President George W Bush promised to bring affordable high-speed internet to all Americans by 2007 during his re-election campaign, with broadband accounting for an increasingly popular usage among people and businesses. The total number of people and businesses on broadband rose by 38% in the year ending June 2004 compared to 23.5 million in June 2003.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has reported that broadband usage in the US has increased significantly since a year ago, with more people and businesses connecting to the internet via high-speed networks. According to the report, there were over 32 million broadband connections by the end of June 2004, an increase of 38% compared to the previous year. This trend is expected to continue as President George W. Bush pledges to ensure affordable high-speed internet access for all Americans by 2007. Overall, broadband usage in the US has increased dramatically over the past year and is now the fastest lane of the internet among developed nations.

While this is a step in the right direction, the US still lags behind other nations, ranked 13th in the world by a UN telecoms body. President George W Bush promised to provide affordable high-speed net access to all Americans by 2007. More people are using broadband for research and shopping, as well as downloading music and watching video. The total number of broadband connections rose from 23.5 million in June 2003 to 32.5 million in June 2004, with cable leading the way at 18.6 million lines.

However, the US still ranks behind other nations in terms of broadband penetration, coming in at 13th place in the world according to a UN telecoms body.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The U.S. broadband user base expanded by 38% annually from June 2003 to June 2004, reaching 32.5 million connections, making it the 13th most connected nation globally, according to a UN telecoms body. President George W. Bush campaigned on providing affordable high-speed internet access to all Americans by 2007. Broadband usage is growing rapidly, with individuals and businesses utilizing it for research, shopping, music downloads, and video streaming. Cable leads as the most prevalent connection type (18.6 million lines), while telephone-based broadband accounts for 11.4 million connections.
reference: Broadband over the phone line makes up 11.4 million connections, according to the FCC figures.The total number of people and businesses on broadband rose by to 32.5 million in the year ending June 2004, compared to 23.5 million in June 2003.In a report, it said there were more than 32 million broadband connections by the end of June 2004.The number of people and business connected to broadband jumped by 38% in a year, said the US Federal Communications Commission (FCC).
